entries.title: US Supreme Court temporarily blocks lifting of asylum restrictions
entries.description: The restrictions, often referred to as Title 42, were put in place under Trump in March 2020. Immigration advocates sued to stop its use saying it goes against obligations to people fleeing to the US to escape persecution.

entries.title: Les Bleus greeted by thousands of fans in Paris after World Cup final loss
entries.description: More than 24 million people – eight out of 10 viewers – watched the final on French television TF1, a record high. Mbappé posted his first message since the loss on social media: "We will be back."

entries.title: Actors Johnny Depp and Amber Heard settle defamation suit
entries.description: The deal includes a $1 million payment from Ms. Heard to Mr. Depp. His lawyers said he will donate that money to charity.

entries.title: Dutch PM apologises for 250 years of slavery
entries.description: Mark Rutte apologized Monday on behalf of his government for the Netherlands’ historical role in slavery and the slave trade.

entries.title: French rugby boss Laporte offers to step down pending corruption appeal
entries.description: Bernard Laporte agreed to be suspended as the French Rugby Federation president on Monday while he fights a suspended two-year sentence on corruption charges.

entries.title: US Capitol riot panel recommends charging Trump with obstruction, insurrection
entries.description: A US House of Representatives panel asked federal prosecutors to charge former US President Donald Trump for his role in last year's assault on the Capitol.

entries.title: The e-mails that helped shape a major scientific paper on the origin of SARS-CoV-2
entries.description: E-mails obtained by American NGOs and journalists show the context in which a paper was written in early 2020 that considered that no type of scenario involving a laboratory was plausible.

entries.title: Three Christmas recipes for two
entries.description: On Christmas eve, cuddle up in front of season five of 'The Crown' and enjoy some little snacks and a festive sandwich, eating with your fingers, and binge-watching the episodes.

entries.title: Apple fined €1 million in France over apps
entries.description: The American technology company was accused of imposing prices on French startups willing to sell their apps on the company's platform.

entries.title: Exiting zero Covid: Xi Jinping's risky gamble
entries.description: As the number of infections soars, the Chinese government is hoping for a boost in growth to justify a new approach to tackling the virus.

entries.title: Conspiracy theorists, homophobes, neo-Nazis: Ten accounts that embody Twitter's change under Elon Musk
entries.description: The billionaire unblocked many accounts, including many profiles leaning toward the far right. Millions of Twitter users said Mr. Musk should step down as head of Twitter on Monday in a poll that he created and promised to abide by.

entries.title: EU members reach compromise on gas price cap
entries.description: It was not immediately clear what conditions were linked to the agreed price cap for natural gas in the bloc.

entries.title: Macron hopes to take advantage of the World Cup effect
entries.description: While he has said that he did not want to 'politicize sport,' the French president put himself on the field alongside the French team during the competition.

entries.title: In liberated Kherson, residents live under the divides left by Russia
entries.description: Through propaganda based on nostalgia for the USSR and generous pension payments, Russian occupation authorities found support among the elderly in Kherson.

entries.title: Ballon D'or winner Karim Benzema hints at end of France career
entries.description: In a post published Monday on Twitter, the 2022 Ballon d'Or, injured and absent from the Qatar World Cup, suggests that he is putting an end to his international career.

entries.title: In Buenos Aires, after Argentina's World Cup win: 'We deserved this joy so much!'
entries.description: Thousands of Argentines took to the streets of Buenos Aires on Sunday to celebrate victory following an epic final against France.

entries.title: In Jordan, anger at government mounts over rising cost of living
entries.description: A senior Jordan police officer was killed by unknown attackers in the southern Jordanian city of Ma'an. It's the latest escalation in protests over high fuel prices that have spread across the kingdom.

entries.title: UK judges rule plan to deport asylum seekers to Rwanda lawful
entries.description: London's High Court dismissed legal challenges by migrants and human rights campaigners but did acknowledge the government had 'not properly' considered' the situations of eight asylum seekers.

entries.title: EU accuses Meta of competition breaches with classified ads
entries.description: The European Commission believes that Facebook users having automatic access to Facebook Marketplace is a breach antitrust rules.

entries.title: Twitter poll closes, users vote in favor of Elon Musk's exit as CEO
entries.description: 57.5% of the 17.5 million Twitter users who voted in the poll on Monday said billionaire Elon Musk should step down as CEO of the social media site.

entries.title: French team Les Bleus expected to greet fans in Paris after World Cup defeat
entries.description: France played its part in one of the most memorable finishes in World Cup history, even though the defending champions failed to retain the title.

entries.title: World Cup 2022: In the end, Qatar wins
entries.description: The World Cup was a symbolic and diplomatic success for its host country. This undeniable success in terms of PR must not, of course, mask all the darker sides of an environmentally-aberrant project also hit by suspicions of corruption and human rights violations.

entries.title: Russia and China to hold joint naval drills
entries.description: China and Russia have drawn closer in recent years as part of what they call a "no-limits" relationship, a counterweight to the global dominance of the United States.

entries.title: Are Hanukkah and Christmas twin holidays?
entries.description: Christmas celebrates the birth of Jesus, whom the Jews do not recognize as the Messiah. But Hanukkah and the Christian holiday have several elements in common.

entries.title: COP15: Historic biodiversity agreement found at Montreal conference
entries.description: 195 countries and the European Union agreed to protect 30% of the planet by 2030, restore 30% of damaged ecosystems, and double resources for protecting nature.

entries.title: Ramaphosa reelected as South Africa's ANC party leader
entries.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa won reelection as head of the ruling African National Congress party on Monday.

entries.title: Five Christmas movies to watch with your family
entries.description: From 'It's a Wonderful Life' to 'How the Grinch Stole Christmas', here are five movies to get you and your little loved ones in the Christmas spirit.

entries.title: The incredible World Cup final as seen by French fans: 'We don't want to go home, we'll cry'
entries.description: Across France, bars were packed with football fans for the final of the World Cup on Sunday, December 18. But in the end, only the Argentines were smiling.

entries.title: France ends visa dispute with Algeria linked to migration
entries.description: France had already announced a resolution of the dispute with Tunisia and Morocco, more than a year after it significantly reduced the number of visas granted to Algerian, Moroccan and Tunisian nationals.

entries.title: EU carbon market reform: A major step forward for Europe's 2030 climate goal
entries.description: An agreement was reached on Sunday between the Commission, the European Parliament and member states. The Council and MEPs still need to vote on it.

entries.title: World Cup 2022: Argentina topples France in a twist-filled final
entries.description: Argentina won its third world title on Sunday at the expense of France (3-3, 4-2 in penalties). Lionel Messi won his first World Cup after a match filled with suspense.

entries.title: World Cup 2022: Kylian Mbappé's unfinished symphony
entries.description: Despite scoring a hat-trick in the final and being the tournament's top scorer, the French striker couldn't stop Les Bleus from losing to Argentina in the final.

entries.title: E.T. model sells for $2.6 mn in auction
entries.description: A maquette of E.T. also sold for $125,000, while one of the bikes used in the film's climatic getaway scene went for $115,000 this weekend.

entries.title: World Cup 2022: Argentina defeats France, wins third title in riveting final
entries.description: Lionel Messi won his first world title after a match full of twists and turns. Kylian Mbappé's hat trick was not enough for Les Bleus, who lost in a penalty shootout (3-3, 4-2).

entries.title: 'Avatar' sequel swamped the competition
entries.description: James Cameron's movie took in an estimated $134 million in North American theaters. International ticket sales brought in an additional $300 million, one of the biggest openings in pandemic times.

entries.title: Franco-Palestinian lawyer Salah Hamouri in Paris after being expelled by Israel
entries.description: He had been held without formal charge in Israeli prisons since March. Salah Hamouri was welcomed by his wife and several dozen supporters at Paris-Charles-de-Gaulle airport.

entries.title: Former anti-corruption prosecutor sentenced to four years in prison in Guatemala
entries.description: Amnesty International considers Virginia Laparra to be a 'prisoner of conscience' and calls for her 'immediate and unconditional release.'

entries.title: Brussels urges Belgians to leave Iran over arrest risk
entries.description: 'All Belgian visitors, including (dual) nationals, are at high risk of arrest, arbitrary detention, and unfair trial,' the Belgian government said in a statement, adding that tourists are also at risk.

entries.title: Biodiversity: 'Anything adopted at the COP15 will be compromised before even being signed'
entries.description: No head of state, apart from Justin Trudeau, has planned to attend the conference. Everyone seems to be acknowledging that whatever is signed in Montreal will have no impact on the course of the world, writes Stéphane Foucart, a journalist for 'Le Monde'.
